abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Export Financial
            Intermediation Loan (EFIL III) Project for Turkey were as
            follows: outcomes were highly satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was highly
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: eligibility
            constraints and reporting requirements that go beyond what
            Participating Financial Intermediaries (PFIs) normally
            require increases transaction cost of the project, slows
            implementation, and may have a tendency to shift funds to
            firms with relatively better access to finance. The
            application process for sub-loans and leases reportedly
            required increased efforts compared to normal lending
            practices but it did contribute to capacity building. It may
            be better to improve PFIs' existing credit appraisal
            practices, simplify requirements for smaller sub-loans and
            borrowers, and require audited sub-borrower data on an
            annual basis (not quarterly). Offering longer maturities to
            PFIs could help further deepen financial intermediation by
            enabling more rollover of funds at PFI level. During the
            project, loan funds for one bank in the project became
            unworkable and will not have continued to disburse. Prompt
            reallocation by Turkish Industrial Development Bank (TSKB)
            to other PFIs ensured that the overall project was not
            delayed as a result.
